title: Sampling Distribution of a Sample Mean: Roll That Dice
question_text:
The roll of a six-sided die has a uniform distribution with a mean outcome of $3.5$ and a standard deviation of approximately $1.708$.
Which of the following best describes the sampling distribution of the sample means when the same dice is rolled $48$ times?

choices.text: Uniform with a ${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }=3.5$ and a $ \sigma _{ \overline { x } }=1.708$
Uniform with a ${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }=3.5$ and a $ \sigma _{ \overline { x } }=\dfrac { 1.708 }{ \sqrt { 48 } } $
Normal with a ${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }=3.5$ and a $\sigma _{ \overline { x } }=\dfrac { 1.708 }{ \sqrt { 48 } } $
Approximately normal with a ${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }=3.5$ and a $ \sigma _{ \overline { x } }=1.708$
Approximately normal with a ${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }=3.5$ and a $ \sigma _{ \overline { x } }=\dfrac { 1.708 }{ \sqrt { 48 } } $

solution:
First, let us discuss the shape of the sampling distribution. Since the shape of the individual rolls were uniform and the sample size is relatively large, $(48 >30)$, then by the Central Limit Theorem, the shape of the sampling distribution is approximately normal.

Explanation of Distractors Choices 'A' and 'B' are incorrect as the shape of the sampling distribution would be approximately normal by the Central Limit Theorem and not uniform. Choice 'A' would also be incorrect as the standard deviation was never divided by the square root of the sample size.

Choice 'C' is incorrect as the shape of the sampling distribution would be approximately normal instead of normal. In order for the shape of the sampling distribution to be normal the shape of the population must be normal.

Choice 'D' is incorrect as the standard deviation was never divided by the square root of the sample size.
